msContents.summary:
Johann Kaspar Diethelm (1706–1767), medical doctor, was the Protestant 'Stadtschreiber' of the mixed-confessional town of Bischofszell from 1728 to his death. In May 1743 a fire broke out which destroyed a great part of the old town. Diethelm started writing a diary soon afterwards, later titled 'Diarium domesticum'. He was no doubt stimulated by the risk of losing the citizenship's collective memory, which he must have felt quite near in the fire. The town was soon rebuilt, also thanks to the solidarity of the whole Confederation.
Also the local Collegium musicum had lost in the fire all its belongings. Diethelm estimated the losses in November 1743 at florins 564.48 worth in musical instruments, scores, and cash. One of the acts of solidarity that Bischofszell citizens experienced was the donation by the Collegium musicum 'auf der deutschen Schule' in Zurich, and by some private persons, of some fifteen music-books in February 1744, which enabled the Bischofszell amateur musicians to resume their activities.
The list of scores lost in 1743 is the first of the two inventories that Diethelm drew of the Collegium's musical collection, the second one being the list of the gifts offered to the Bischofszell music society early in 1744. Of this second inventory (to be precise, of its first twelve items) there exists a mirror image in the protocols of the donor, the Zurich society 'auf der deutschen Schule' (CH-Zz, AMG Archiv IV A 4, p. 494).
